hedline.hl1: National Briefing | Science And Health: Drop In Emissions

abstract.p: Energy Department reports emissions of heat-trapping carbon dioxide fell by 1.1 percent in 2001, first annual drop in American emissions since 1991, mostly as result of sharp dip in manufacturing; emissions from other sources rose (S)

block.p: The economy slowdown and the warm winter last year caused the first annual drop in American emissions of heat-trapping carbon dioxide since 1991, the Department of Energy said. Carbon dioxide, released by the burning of fossil fuels, has been linked to rising global temperatures. Through the 1990's, emissions from energy use rose an average of 1.2 percent a year. Last year, they fell by 1.1 percent, with most of the drop coming as a result of a sharp dip in manufacturing. Emissions from transportation, housing and other kinds of businesses rose.
